title: Anyone see a g like this?
content:
I was sketching around this morning and wondered if anyone had ever seen a font with a lowercase g that was two-story style but with a disconnected descender, like so:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318im_/http:/typophile.com/files/g_6273.png)

The image up there is something I slapped together in Photoshop, since I can't think of or find any fonts that have a similarly styled g.

Peace,  
JT
author: jt_the_ninja

comments.content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318im_/http:/typophile.com/files/renner_5948.jpg)

Paul Renner's original Futura g, available as Architype Renner from [The Foundry](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318/http:/www.foundrytypes.co.uk/).

That is truly an awesome g.

And a crazy i as well. Thanks.

Peace,  
JT

can't think of any retail releases.  
here are a couple of other things

[an unreleased version of ink gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318/http:/www.agency26.com/inkdisplay.jpg)

[not inspired by Renner's g, but maybe subconsciously](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318/http:/www.agency26.com/million3.png)
I saw a g like that a while back, but I cannot for the life of me remember what it was and where. So this is a pretty useless comment, but maybe I'll remember what it was later. ;)

Jack Usine's Vidange, which was the featured font here on Typophile not too long ago, has an (IMO, awesome) disconnected "g".  
 [http://www.psyops.com/html/spec\_vidange.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_vidange.html "http://www.psyops.com/html/spec\_vidange.html")

OK, I found another (borderline legible) one by digging through some old threads. This makes Renner's original Futura "g" above look complex:  
Egret Light  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/device\_fonts/egret\_light/?&sample\_...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/device_fonts/egret_light/?&sample_text=g&sample_size=388 "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/device\_fonts/egret\_light/?&sample\_text=g&sample\_size=388")

A-ha! Thanks for the replies. Good to know I'm not crazy in thinking the disconnected g is a cool idea.

I was playing around with the pen tool today after I made the g I posted, just to see what the disconnected descender would look like in a string of text (this was before there were any replies):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318im_/http:/typophile.com/files/g_globe_4626.png)

Not actually a bad stylistic choice, IMO.

Peace,  
JT

\> And a crazy i as well.

Believe it or not, it’s an r.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215224318im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Text-ArchitypeOne1_5015.gif)

Whoa, I would never have guessed it was an r out of context...weird.

Peace,  
JT
